In my matplotlib code, I'm trying to set the facecolor of the figure to red using the methods `fig1.patch` and `rect.set_facecolor('red')`. However, when I save the figure using `plt.savefig("trial_fig.png")`, the saved figure does not have the red facecolor. On the other hand, the figure height and width specified using `fig1.set_figheight(11)` and `fig1.set_figwidth(8.5)` are correctly picked up by `plt.savefig("trial_fig.png")`. Can someone explain why the facecolor setting is not applied when saving the figure?

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# create figure instance
fig1 = plt.figure(1)
fig1.set_figheight(11)
fig1.set_figwidth(8.5)

rect = fig1.patch
rect.set_facecolor('red') # works with plt.show().  
                          # Does not work with plt.savefig("trial_fig.png")

ax = fig1.add_subplot(1,1,1)

x = 1, 2, 3
y = 1, 4, 9
ax.plot(x, y)

# plt.show()  # Will show red face color set above using rect.set_facecolor('red')

plt.savefig("trial_fig.png") # The saved trial_fig.png DOES NOT have the red facecolor.

# plt.savefig("trial_fig.png", facecolor='red') # Here the facecolor is red.
```

When saving figures using `plt.savefig()` in Matplotlib, the default behavior is to not include the figure's facecolor unless explicitly specified. This is why the facecolor set via `rect.set_facecolor('red')` is not applied to the saved figure. However, the dimensions set by `set_figheight()` and `set_figwidth()` are applied because they are inherent properties of the figure.

To ensure the facecolor is applied when saving the figure, you need to specify the `facecolor` parameter directly in the `plt.savefig()` call. This parameter explicitly sets the facecolor of the entire figure in the saved file. Here is how you can modify your code:

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# create figure instance
fig1 = plt.figure(1)
fig1.set_figheight(11)
fig1.set_figwidth(8.5)

rect = fig1.patch
rect.set_facecolor('red') # This will be shown in plt.show()

ax = fig1.add_subplot(1,1,1)

x = [1, 2, 3]
y = [1, 4, 9]
ax.plot(x, y)

# Save the figure with the facecolor specified
plt.savefig("trial_fig.png", facecolor='red') # Specify facecolor here
```

By adding `facecolor='red'` to the `plt.savefig()` function, the saved figure will have the desired facecolor.
